repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Adds the capability of controlling the priority of searched markers in vim.fs.root() by nesting lists.

Fix: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34258

I'm not sure whether to add tests or not because the test added in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/33485/ already covers the use case of this comprehensively. Perhaps copying that over to `fs_spec.lua` would be desirable. I'm not sure.

comment_data.body: I find this type to be really hard to read. The description could help by maybe explaining that a marker is of the type `string|string[]|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean`, and that this parameter can be a single element of that type or a list of them.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3223,10 +3223,17 @@ vim.fs.root({source}, {marker})                                *vim.fs.root()*
       • {source}  (`integer|string`) Buffer number (0 for current buffer) or
                   file path (absolute or relative to the |current-directory|)
                   to begin the search from.
-      • {marker}  (`string|string[]|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean`)
+      • {marker}  (`string|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean|(string|string[]|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean)[]`)

comment_data.body: I have updated the description. Hopefully it's more descriptive and easier to understand now.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3223,10 +3223,17 @@ vim.fs.root({source}, {marker})                                *vim.fs.root()*
       • {source}  (`integer|string`) Buffer number (0 for current buffer) or
                   file path (absolute or relative to the |current-directory|)
                   to begin the search from.
-      • {marker}  (`string|string[]|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean`)
+      • {marker}  (`string|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean|(string|string[]|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean)[]`)

@@ -3223,10 +3223,17 @@ vim.fs.root({source}, {marker})                                *vim.fs.root()*
       • {source}  (`integer|string`) Buffer number (0 for current buffer) or
                   file path (absolute or relative to the |current-directory|)
                   to begin the search from.
-      • {marker}  (`string|string[]|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean`)
+      • {marker}  (`string|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean|(string|string[]|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean)[]`)

@@ -415,16 +430,30 @@ function M.root(source, marker)
     error('invalid type for argument "source": expected string or buffer number')
   end
 
-  local paths = M.find(marker, {
-    upward = true,
-    path = vim.fn.fnamemodify(path, ':p:h'),
-  })
+  local marker_t = type(marker)
+  if marker_t == 'string' or marker_t == 'function' then
+    local paths = M.find(marker, {
+      upward = true,
+      path = vim.fn.fnamemodify(path, ':p:h'),
+    })
 
-  if #paths == 0 then
-    return nil
+    if #paths ~= 0 then
+      return vim.fs.dirname(paths[1])
+    end
+  else
+    for _, mark in ipairs(marker) do
+      local paths = M.find(mark, {
+        upward = true,
+        path = vim.fn.fnamemodify(path, ':p:h'),
+      })
+
+      if #paths ~= 0 then
+        return vim.fs.dirname(paths[1])
+      end
+    end

comment_data.body:
do we need a test for the heterogeneous case (where some item(s) is a function)?

    [[return vim.fs.root(..., { function() ... end, 'example_spec.lua', '.luarc.json'})]],
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -366,6 +366,24 @@ describe('vim.fs', function()
       )
     end)
 
+    it('assings priorities according to nested markers', function()
+      local bufnr = api.nvim_get_current_buf()
+      eq(
+        vim.fs.joinpath(test_source_path, 'test/functional'),
+        exec_lua(
+          [[return vim.fs.root(..., { 'example_spec.lua', {'CMakeLists.txt', 'CMakePresets.json'}, '.luarc.json'})]],
+          bufnr
+        )
+      )
+      eq(
+        vim.fs.joinpath(test_source_path, 'test/functional/fixtures'),
+        exec_lua(
+          [[return vim.fs.root(..., { {'CMakeLists.txt', 'CMakePresets.json'}, 'example_spec.lua', '.luarc.json'})]],

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
• |vim.fs.root()| can define "equal priority" via nested lists.
```

 • |vim.tbl_extend()| and |vim.tbl_deep_extend()| now accept a function behavior argument.
+• |vim.fs.root()| now allows assigning priorities by nesting lists in the
+  marker.

@@ -366,6 +366,24 @@ describe('vim.fs', function()

comment_data.body:
typo
```suggestion
    it('nested markers have equal priority', function()
```

comment_regular_data.body:
> Perhaps copying that over to `fs_spec.lua` would be desirable

yes, something like that.
Added the test. The test in `lsp_spec.lua` was pretty lsp specific, so I just wrote one similar to the tests already in `fs_spec.lua`.

It is. I am not sure how to resolve it. `(string|string[])[]` should be a subtype of the `(string|func|string[])[]` type that `vim.fs.root` accepts but luals doesn't seem to like it. I could change the type of `root_markers` or add the `(string|string[])[]` type to `vim.fs.root`, not sure which one is the better solution
if luals is wrong, just cast at the caller using `--[[@as ...]]`
Fixed it! Reordering the typing in `vim.fs.root` makes the linter stop complaining due to how luals does the typechecking.

Backport failed for `release-0.11`, because it was unable to cherry-pick the commit(s).

Please cherry-pick the changes locally and resolve any conflicts.
```bash
git fetch origin release-0.11
git worktree add -d .worktree/backport-34276-to-release-0.11 origin/release-0.11
cd .worktree/backport-34276-to-release-0.11
git switch --create backport-34276-to-release-0.11
git cherry-pick -x 2f0fbdaa480c5b014b68bfdb85aa105d0bef3637
```

title: feat(vim.fs) vim.fs.root() can control priority
